001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.glutils.ShaderProgram;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulBatch;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulSprite;
008
009/**
010 * Shader code to construct a {@link ShaderProgram} that can render the specialized colors produced by the rest of this
011 * library. The shader code is meant for use in a {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch}; a convenience
012 * method, {@link #makeBatch()}, is provided to generate and return a SpriteBatch that uses a correct ShaderProgram.
013 * Many of the shaders here are experimental and meant as a basis for user code, rather than a complete solution.
014 * If you aren't familiar with shaders in libGDX, <a href="https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Shaders">see this
015 * libGDX wiki article</a> for more information.
016 * <br>
017 * None of the shaders here specify a {@code #version}, and some combinations of OS, driver, and GPU hardware may
018 * require the version to be set to a specific value. You may need to put:
019 * {@code ShaderProgram.prependVertexCode = "#version 110\n";
020 * ShaderProgram.prependFragmentCode = "#version 110\n";} in your launchers, with whatever version you can support, in
021 * order to avoid some warnings or errors on some systems.
022 * <br>
023 * Many of these shaders would need at least some changing to work with kinds of
024 * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch} that aren't SpriteBatch (or at least very similar). You should compare
025 * the names of {@code uniform} variables in the vertex and fragment shader if you use a different kind of Batch; if all
026 * of them are the same and there are the same amount, then you should be able to use these shaders without issue.
027 * <br>
028 * Note that you don't need to specify a shader from here at all if you use a ColorfulBatch from this library!
029 * There is a ColorfulBatch in each of the color space subpackages, such as {@code rgb}, {@code oklab}, and {@code ipt}.
030 * All of those allow a multiplicative "tweak" to each color channel before an additive change is applied to that
031 * channel; to contrast, all of the shaders here can only permit one or the other for a given channel. ColorfulBatch may
032 * act oddly if it has to interact with SpriteBatch-specific classes like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Sprite},
033 * so there are ColorfulSprite classes that also allow setting the "tweak" and additive change per-sprite. Still, it can
034 * be a good idea to use the shaders here if you have an existing SpriteBatch, or want to use the various experimental
035 * shaders as a test-bed.
036 */
037public class Shaders {
038    /**
039     * This is the default vertex shader from libGDX. It is used without change by most of the fragment shaders here.
040     */
041    public static final String vertexShader = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
042            + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
043            + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
044            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
045            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
046            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
047            + "\n"
048            + "void main()\n"
049            + "{\n"
050            + "   v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
051            + "   v_color.a = v_color.a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
052            + "   v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
053            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
054            + "}\n";
055    /*
056attribute vec4 a_position;
057attribute vec4 a_color;
058attribute vec2 a_texCoord0;
059uniform mat4 u_projTrans;
060varying vec4 v_color;
061varying vec2 v_texCoords;
062
063void main()
064{
065   v_color = a_color;
066   v_color.a = v_color.a * (255.0/254.0);
067   v_texCoords = a_texCoord0;
068   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * a_position;
069}
070     */
071
072    /**
073     * A simple shader that uses additive blending with "normal" RGBA colors (alpha is still multiplicative).
074     * With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%,
075     * and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color,
076     * white adds 0.5 to the RGB channels (brightening it and also desaturating it), and black subtracts 0.5 from the
077     * RGB channels (darkening and desaturating, but not to black unless the color is already somewhat dark). When
078     * tinting with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/iAb1rig.png">The Mona Lisa on the left</a>, when
079     * tinting with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it almost reaches all black, but some
080     * faint part of the image is still barely visible.
081     * <br>
082     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
083     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
084     * <br>
085     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
086     */
087    public static final String fragmentShaderRGBA =
088            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
089                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
090                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
091                    "#else\n" +
092                    "#define LOWP \n" +
093                    "#endif\n" +
094                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
095                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
096                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
097                    "void main()\n" +
098                    "{\n" +
099                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
100                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(tgt.rgb * pow((v_color.rgb + 0.1) * 1.666, vec3(1.5)), v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
101                    "}";
102    /**
103     * A simple shader that uses multiplicative blending with "normal" RGBA colors, and is simpler than
104     * {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA} but can make changes in color smoother. With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram,
105     * white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%, and black darkens a color to black, but
106     * nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color, white multiplies the RGB channels by
107     * 2.0 (brightening it and slightly desaturating it), and black multiplies the RGB channels by 0 (reducing the color
108     * always to black). When tinting with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/I30jeXv.png">The Mona
109     * Lisa on the left</a>; when tinting with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it produces an
110     * all-black image.
111     * <br>
112     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
113     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
114     * <br>
115     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
116     * <br>
117     * An earlier version of this attempted to use some useful code by CypherCove in gdx-tween, but the current version
118     * doesn't share any code, and doesn't really do any gamma correction either. It does less... gamma... un-correction
119     * than {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA}, though, so if the source images are gamma-corrected this should be fine.
120     */
121    public static final String fragmentShaderGammaRGBA =
122            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
123                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
124                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
125                    "#else\n" +
126                    "#define LOWP \n" +
127                    "#endif\n" +
128                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
129                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
130                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
131                    "void main()\n" +
132                    "{\n" +
133                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
134                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb * 2.0, v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
135                    "}";
136    //// save the result as shader, and set it on your batch with
137    // ShaderProgram shader = makeRGBAShader();
138    // batch.setShader(shader)
139    /**
140     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
141     * lighten an image. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
142     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
143     * <br>
144     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
145     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
146     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA}
147     */
148    public static ShaderProgram makeRGBAShader()
149    {
150        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderRGBA);
151        if(!shader.isCompiled())
152            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
153        return shader;
154    }
155    /**
156     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
157     * lighten an image, and also smooths changes well. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
158     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
159     * <br>
160     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
161     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
162     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderGammaRGBA}
163     */
164    public static ShaderProgram makeGammaRGBAShader()
165    {
166        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderGammaRGBA);
167        if(!shader.isCompiled())
168            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
169        return shader;
170    }
171
172    /**
173     * Where the magic happens; this converts a batch color from the YCwCm format (used by colorful's ycwcm package) to
174     * RGBA. The vertex color will be split up into 4 channels just as a normal shader does, but the channels here are
175     * luma, chromatic warmth, chromatic mildness, and alpha; alpha acts just like a typical RGBA shader, but the others
176     * are additive instead of multiplicative, with 0.5 as a neutral value. This does not support the "tweak" features
177     * that {@link ColorfulBatch} does, which include multiplicative counterparts to the additive operations this
178     * supports on luma, chromatic warmth, and chromatic mildness, plus a contrast adjustment. If you want to adjust
179     * contrast globally, you can use {@link #makeBatch(float)} to set the contrast for a new Batch with a new shader.
180     * <br>
181     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
182     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
183     * <br>
184     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
185     */
186    public static final String fragmentShader =
187            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
188                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
189                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
190                    "#else\n" +
191                    "#define LOWP \n" +
192                    "#endif\n" +
193                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
194                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
195                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
196                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125);\n" +
197                    "void main()\n" +
198                    "{\n" +
199                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
200                    "////use the following line to match the color exactly\n" +
201                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + dot(tgt.rgb, bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
202                    "////use the following line to increase contrast\n" +
203                    "//   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * dot(sin(tgt.rgb * 1.5707963267948966) * sqrt(tgt.rgb), bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
204                    "////use the following line to increase contrast more\n" +
205                    "//   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), 1.25), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
206                    //uses a specific matrix (related to bright, above) multiplied with ycc to get back to rgb.
207                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4( (clamp(mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.625, -0.375, -0.375, -0.5, 0.5, -0.5) * ycc, 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
208                    "}";
209    /**
210     * A variant on {@link #fragmentShader} that adjusts luma to make mid-range colors darker, while keeping light
211     * colors light. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's tweak is
212     * the same as what this uses (1.375 here, which is roughly 0.875f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does some work
213     * in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe effects on
214     * the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
215     * <br>
216     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
217     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
218     * <br>
219     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
220     */
221    public static final String fragmentShaderHigherContrast =
222            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
223                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
224                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
225                    "#else\n" +
226                    "#define LOWP \n" +
227                    "#endif\n" +
228                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
229                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
230                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
231                    "const float contrast =    1.375   ; // You can make contrast a uniform if you want.\n" +
232                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125) * (4.0 / 3.0);\n" +
233                    "void main()\n" +
234                    "{\n" +
235                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
236                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), contrast) * 0.75, ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
237                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4( (clamp(mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.625, -0.375, -0.375, -0.5, 0.5, -0.5) * ycc, 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
238                    "}";
239
240    /**
241     * An alternative shader that effectively reduces luma contrast, bringing all but the darkest colors to the
242     * upper-mid luma range. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's
243     * tweak is the same as what this uses (0.625 here, which is roughly 0.125f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does
244     * some work in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe
245     * effects on the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
246     * <br>
247     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
248     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
249     * <br>
250     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
251     */
252    public static final String fragmentShaderLowerContrast = fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", "0.625");
253
254    /**
255     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShader}
256     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the ycwcm package. It won't be a
257     * {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways); you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to
258     * make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces won't be able to render a {@link ColorfulSprite},
259     * but ColorfulBatch can.
260     * <br>
261     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
262     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
263     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
264     */
265    public static SpriteBatch makeBatch()
266    {
267        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShader);
268        if(!shader.isCompiled())
269            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
270        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
271    }
272
273    /**
274     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShader}
275     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the ycwcm package. This also takes a
276     * {@code contrast} parameter; if greater than 1.0 it will make light colors lighter and dark colors darker, while
277     * if it is less than 1.0 it will make all but the darkest colors closer to the upper-middle-range of lightness.
278     * If you want to adjust contrast per-sprite, use a {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways);
279     * you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces
280     * won't be able to render a {@link ColorfulSprite}, but ColorfulBatch can. ColorfulBatch also will calculate
281     * contrast differently from the shader this uses, including doing some work in the vertex shader (which may be
282     * faster). It also takes a contrast in its tweak value that is limited to a 0.0 to 1.0 range, rather than 0.1 to
283     * 2.0 here (this can technically tolerate 0.01 to 10.0, but those extremes aren't recommended).
284     * <br>
285     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
286     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
287     * @param contrast how much contrast should be emphasized; higher than 1.0 is more contrasting, and this should usually be between 0.1 and 2.0
288     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
289     */
290    public static SpriteBatch makeBatch(final float contrast)
291    {
292        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", Float.toString(Math.min(Math.max(contrast, 0.01f), 10f))));
293        if(!shader.isCompiled())
294            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
295        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
296    }
297
298    /**
299     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses {@link #vertexShaderHSLC} and {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}
300     * from this class, making it interpret the SpriteBatch's color, as set by 
301     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, to be hue rotation, saturation change, lightness
302     * change, and contrast change. All of these are neutral when their value is 0.5f. Hue rotates clockwise or
303     * counterclockwise when it goes toward 0.0, and the other way when it goes toward 1.0; 0.0 and 1.0 both refer to
304     * the 180 degree rotation, but I don't know which goes which way (it also depends on how you visualize hue).
305     * Saturation becomes more grayscale as it goes towards 0.0, and more vivid as it goes towards 1.0. Lightness gets
306     * darker towards 0.0, lighter towards 1.0 (any lightness above 0.5 will brighten the image, unlike the default
307     * shader and batch color). Contrast affects changes in lightness; low contrast makes all lightness closer to the
308     * mid-range, while high contrast makes even small changes in the mid-range of an image's color have stark lightness
309     * changes in the result. Note, this does not support changing an image's alpha with the batch color.
310     * <br>
311     * You can generate HSLC colors using {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}, using the last
312     * parameter to store contrast.
313     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering HSLC
314     */
315    public static SpriteBatch makeBatchHSLC()
316    {
317        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShaderHSLC, fragmentShaderHSLC);
318        if(!shader.isCompiled())
319            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
320        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
321    }
322
323    /**
324     * Similar to {@link #fragmentShader}, but this uses the very perceptually-accurate IPT color space as described by
325     * Ebner and Fairchild, instead of the custom YCwCm color space. IPT doesn't really need that much more computation
326     * to be done by the shader, but tends to make gradual changes in color much smoother. If comparing to YCwCm, then
327     * Y (luma) is like I (intensity) here, so when a Batch color has 0 for I (stored in the r channel), it makes the
328     * image very dark, while if the Batch color has 1 for I, it makes the image very light. Cw and Cm can be graphed
329     * like a color wheel, and in their case, the 4 corners of a square graph are red, yellow, green, and blue. IPT is
330     * less geometrical, and the corners are roughly purple, orange, green, and cyan, while the centers of the edges of
331     * the square are close to red, yellow, green, and blue. <a href="https://i.imgur.com/A3n4qmM.png">See this capture
332     * of the IPT space</a> if you want a better picture. The P (short for protan, a term from ophthalmology) channel
333     * (stored in g) is the left-to-right axis there, with P==0 making colors green or blue (cooler), and P==1 making
334     * colors orange, red, or purple (somewhat warmer). The T (short for tritan, also from ophthalmology) channel
335     * (stored in b) is the down-to-up axis there, with T==0 making colors more blue or purple, and T==1 making colors
336     * more green, yellow, brown, or orange. Where protan can be viewed as going from cool to warm as its value
337     * increases, tritan can be viewed as going from artificial to natural, or perhaps fluid to solid. Alpha is treated
338     * exactly as it is in the standard libGDX fragment shader, with the alpha in the batch color multiplied by the
339     * alpha in the image pixel to get the result alpha.
340     * <br>
341     * You can generate IPT colors using any of various methods in the {@code ipt} package, such as
342     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}. Note that IPT is
343     * intended to share an API with the {@code ipt_hq} package, but IPT_HQ is usually preferred.
344     * <br>
345     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
346     */
347    public static String fragmentShaderIPT =
348            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
349                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
350                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
351                    "#else\n" +
352                    "#define LOWP \n" +
353                    "#endif\n" +
354                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
355                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
356                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
357                    "void main()\n" +
358                    "{\n" +
359                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
360                    "    vec4 adj = v_color;\n" +
361                    "    adj.yz = adj.yz * 2.0 - 0.5;\n" +
362                    "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
363                    "         * (tgt.rgb)) + adj.xyz - 0.5;\n" +
364                    "    ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
365                    "    ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
366                    "    vec3 back = mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt;\n" +
367                    "    gl_FragColor = vec4(clamp(back, 0.0, 1.0), adj.a * tgt.a);\n" +
368                    "}";
369    /**
370     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but gamma-corrects the input and output RGB values (which improves
371     * lightness uniformity) and uses an exponential step internally to change how colors are distributed within the
372     * gamut. These steps are more computationally expensive than the bare-bones ones in {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but
373     * they seem to improve some aspects of color transitions quite a bit.
374     * <br>
375     * You can generate IPT_HQ colors using any of various methods in the {@code ipt_hq} package, such as
376     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt_hq.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}. Note that IPT_HQ is
377     * intended to share an API with the {@code ipt} package, but IPT_HQ is usually preferred.
378     * <br>
379     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
380     */
381    public static String fragmentShaderIPT_HQ =
382            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
383                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
384                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
385                    "#else\n" +
386                    "#define LOWP \n" +
387                    "#endif\n" +
388                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
389                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
390                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
391                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(0.43);\n" +
392                    "const vec3 reverse = vec3(1.0 / 0.43);\n" +
393                    "void main()\n" +
394                    "{\n" +
395                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
396                    "  vec3 ipt = mat3(0.40000, 4.45500, 0.80560, 0.40000, -4.8510, 0.35720, 0.20000, 0.39600, -1.1628) *" +
397                    "             pow(mat3(0.313921, 0.151693, 0.017753, 0.639468, 0.748209, 0.109468, 0.0465970, 0.1000044, 0.8729690) \n" +
398                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
399                    "  ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x + v_color.x - 0.55, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
400                    "  ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz + v_color.yz * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
401                    "  ipt = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.097569, -0.11388, 0.032615, 0.205226, 0.133217, -0.67689) * ipt;\n" +
402                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
403                    "                 mat3(5.432622, -1.10517, 0.028104, -4.67910, 2.311198, -0.19466, 0.246257, -0.20588, 1.166325) *\n" +
404                    "                 (sign(ipt) * pow(abs(ipt), reverse))," +
405                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
406                    "}";
407
408    /**
409     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT_HQ}, but uses the Oklab color space instead of the very similar IPT_HQ one.
410     * This also gamma-corrects the inputs and outputs, though it uses subtly different math internally. Oklab colors
411     * tend to have more variation on their L channel, which represents lightness, than their A or B channels, which
412     * represent green-to-red and blue-to-yellow chromatic axes; indeed, A and B tend to be no more than about 1/6 away
413     * from their middle point at 1/2, which is used for grayscale. This is normal for Oklab, and allows colors to be
414     * compared for approximate difference using Euclidean distance. Importantly, Oklab preserves the meaning of its L
415     * channel (lightness) very well when comparing two arbitrary colors, while also doing well when comparing chroma
416     * (see {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#chroma(float)}.
417     * <br>
418     * You can generate Oklab colors using any of various methods in the {@code oklab} package, such as
419     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}.
420     * <br>
421     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
422     */
423    public static String fragmentShaderOklab =
424            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
425                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
426                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
427                    "#else\n" +
428                    "#define LOWP \n" +
429                    "#endif\n" +
430                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
431                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
432                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
433                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n" +
434                    "float toOklab(float L) {\n" +
435                    "        const float shape = 0.64516133, turning = 0.95;\n" +
436                    "        float d = turning - L;\n" +
437                    "        float r = mix(\n" +
438                    "          ((1. - turning) * (L - 1.)) / (1. - (L + shape * d)) + 1.,\n" +
439                    "          (turning * L) / (1.0e-20 + (L + shape * d)),\n" +
440                    "          step(0.0, d));\n" +
441                    "        return r * r;\n" +
442                    "}\n" +
443                    "float fromOklab(float L) {\n" +
444                    "        const float shape = 1.55, turning = 0.95;\n" +
445                    "        L = sqrt(L);\n" +
446                    "        float d = turning - L;\n" +
447                    "        return mix(\n" +
448                    "          ((1. - turning) * (L - 1.)) / (1. - (L + shape * d)) + 1.,\n" +
449                    "          (turning * L) / (1.0e-20 + (L + shape * d)),\n" +
450                    "          step(0.0, d));\n" +
451                    "}\n" +
452//                    "float toOklab(float L) {\n" +
453//                    "  return (L - 1.0) / (1.0 - L * 0.4285714) + 1.0;\n" +
454//                    "}\n" +
455//                    "float fromOklab(float L) {\n" +
456//                    "  return (L - 1.0) / (1.0 + L * 0.75) + 1.0;\n" +
457//                    "}\n" +
458                    "void main()\n" +
459                    "{\n" +
460                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
461                    "  vec3 lab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *" +
462                    "             pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n" +
463                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
464                    "  lab.x = fromOklab(clamp(toOklab(lab.x) + v_color.r - 0.5, 0.0, 1.0));\n" +
465                    "  lab.yz = clamp(lab.yz + v_color.gb * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
466                    "  lab = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, +0.3963377774, -0.1055613458, -0.0894841775, +0.2158037573, -0.0638541728, -1.2914855480) * lab;\n" +
467                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
468                    "                 mat3(+4.0767245293, -1.2681437731, -0.0041119885, -3.3072168827, +2.6093323231, -0.7034763098, +0.2307590544, -0.3411344290, +1.7068625689) *\n" +
469                    "                 (lab * lab * lab)," +
470                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
471                    "}";
472
473    /**
474     * A vertex shader that does the bulk of processing HSI-format batch colors and converting them to a format
475     * {@link #fragmentShaderHSI} can use. Since HSI is only a cylindrical/spherical adaptation of IPT, with identical
476     * I components and the combination of H and S in polar coordinates mapping to P and T in Cartesian coordinates,
477     * the fragment shader this is used with can be any that expects an IPT color (currently only
478     * {@link #fragmentShaderIPT} does this, and it's the same as {@link #fragmentShaderHSI}). This vertex shader does
479     * a lot more than most vertex shaders here, but since it is executed relatively rarely (unless you're drawing many
480     * 1-pixel textures), there shouldn't be a heavy performance penalty.
481     * <br>
482     * There is no special code to generate HSI colors; you can use
483     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, or any ColorTools
484     * method that generates a packed float color directly from the channel values, to specify hue, saturation,
485     * intensity, and alpha in that order. You can also just specify the batch color directly with
486     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, taking the channels in the same order as above.
487     * <br>
488     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
489     */
490    public static final String vertexShaderHSI = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
491        + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
492        + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
493        + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
494        + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
495        + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
496        + "const vec3 yellow  = vec3( 0.16155326,0.020876605,-0.26078433 );\n"
497        + "const vec3 magenta = vec3(-0.16136102,0.122068435,-0.070396   );\n"
498        + "const vec3 cyan    = vec3( 0.16420607,0.3481738,   0.104959644);\n"
499        + "void main()\n"
500        + "{\n"
501        + "    v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
502        + "    v_color.a = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ".a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
503        + "    vec3 hsi = v_color.rgb;\n"
504        + "    v_color.x = (hsi.z - 0.5) * 0.9999;\n"
505        + "    hsi.x *= 6.28318;\n"
506        + "    hsi.y *= 0.5;\n"
507        + "    v_color.y = cos(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
508        + "    v_color.z = sin(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
509        + "    float crMid = dot(cyan.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
510        + "    float mgMid = dot(magenta.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
511        + "    float ybMid = dot(yellow.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
512        + "    float crScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(crMid, 0.0)) * cyan.x / (0.00001 - crMid);\n"
513        + "    float mgScale = (v_color.x + 0.5 - step(mgMid, 0.0)) * magenta.x / (0.00001 - mgMid);\n"
514        + "    float ybScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(ybMid, 0.0)) * yellow.x / (0.00001 - ybMid);\n"
515        + "    float scale = 4.0 * min(crScale, min(mgScale, ybScale));\n"
516        + "    v_color.yz *= scale * length(v_color.yz) / cos(3.14159 * v_color.x);\n"
517        + "    v_color.xyz += 0.5;\n"
518        + "    v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
519        + "    gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
520        + "}\n";
521    /**
522     * This is an alias for {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}. If used with {@link #vertexShaderHSI}, you can specify a batch
523     * color using an HSL-like system.
524     * <br>
525     * There is no special code to generate HSI colors; you can use
526     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, or any ColorTools
527     * method that generates a packed float color directly from the channel values, to specify hue, saturation,
528     * intensity, and alpha in that order. You can also just specify the batch color directly with
529     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, taking the channels in the same order as above.
530     * <br>
531     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShaderHSI}.
532     */
533    public static String fragmentShaderHSI = fragmentShaderIPT;
534
535    /**
536     * Not a full shader, this is a snippet used by most of the other HSL-based shaders to implement the complex
537     * rgb2hsl() and hsl2rgb() methods. There are also comments in the code snippet that you can use if you want to
538     * change the distribution of colors across the color wheel.
539     * <br>
540     * Credit to Sam Hocevar, https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808 .
541     * <br>
542     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
543     */
544    public static final String partialCodeHSL =
545                    "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
546                    "////Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a\n" +
547                    "////different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).\n" +
548                    "//float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
549                    "//    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
550                    "//          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
551                    "//          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
552                    "//          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
553                    "//          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
554                    "//          + hue *   5.883)))));\n" +
555                    "//}\n" +
556                    "////Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a\n" +
557                    "////different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).\n" +
558                    "//float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
559                    "//    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
560                    "//          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
561                    "//          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
562                    "//          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
563                    "//          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
564                    "//          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
565                    "//}\n" +
566                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
567                    "{\n" +
568                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
569                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
570                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
571                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
572                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
573                    "    return vec4(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps)), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
574                    "}\n" +
575                    "\n" +
576                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
577                    "{\n" +
578                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
579                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(c.x + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
580                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
581                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
582                    "}";
583
584    /**
585     * Adjusted-hue version of {@link #partialCodeHSL}, supplying HSL to-and-from RGB conversions with a smaller range
586     * of hue used for cyan and a larger range for orange. Not currently used. This is pretty much only meant so people
587     * reading the source code and trying different variations on HSL can see some of the attempts I made.
588     * <br>
589     * Credit to Sam Hocevar, https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808 .
590     * <br>
591     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
592     */
593    public static final String partialCodeHSLStretched =
594            "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
595                    //// maybe not blue enough?
596//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
597//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
598//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
599//                    "    return  hue * (  1.630\n" +
600//                    "          + hue * (  5.937\n" +
601//                    "          + hue * (-38.485\n" +
602//                    "          + hue * ( 76.101\n" +
603//                    "          + hue * (-63.977\n" +
604//                    "          + hue *   19.794)))));\n" +
605//                    "}\n" +
606//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
607//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
608//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
609//                    "    return  hue * (  1.463\n" +
610//                    "          + hue * ( -9.834\n" +
611//                    "          + hue * ( 31.153\n" +
612//                    "          + hue * (-35.066\n" +
613//                    "          + hue *   13.284))));\n" +
614//                    "}\n" +
615                    //// still weirdly high orange
616//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
617//                    "    return  hue * (  2.634\n" +
618//                    "          + hue * ( -4.703\n" +
619//                    "          + hue * (  3.659\n" +
620//                    "          + hue * (  0.829\n" +
621//                    "          + hue *   -1.419))));\n" +
622//                    "}\n" +
623//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
624//                    "    return  hue * (  1.163\n" +
625//                    "          + hue * ( -7.102\n" +
626//                    "          + hue * ( 22.709\n" +
627//                    "          + hue * (-25.502\n" +
628//                    "          + hue *    9.732))));\n" +
629//                    "}\n" +
630//                    "const float ROOT   = 16.0;\n" +
631//                    "const float SQUARE = ROOT * ROOT;\n" +
632                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
633//                    "    return (sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 1.333;\n" +
634//                    "    return asin(sqrt(hue * SQUARE) * (1.0 / ROOT)) * (2.0 * 3.14159274);\n" +
635
636//                    "    return asin((sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 2.666 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
637
638//                    "    return sqrt(sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274) * 0.5 + 0.5);\n" +
639//                    "    return pow(hue, 0.5625);\n" +
640//                    "    return sqrt(hue);\n" +
641                    "    return (sqrt(hue + 0.050625) - 0.225) * 1.25;\n" +
642                    "}\n" +
643                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
644//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
645//                    "    hue = (hue) * 0.75 + 0.25;\n" +
646                    
647//                    "    hue = sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274);\n" +
648//                    "    hue = (hue + 1.0) * 0.375 + 0.25;\n" +
649//                    "    return (hue * hue - 0.0625) * (1.0 / 0.9375);\n" +
650                    
651//                    "    return asin(hue * hue * 2.0 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
652//                    "    return pow(hue, 1.77777);\n" +
653                    "    return pow(hue * 0.8 + 0.225, 2.0) - 0.050625;\n" +
654//                    "    return hue * hue;\n" +
655
656//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
657//                    "    hue = hue * ROOT;\n" +
658//                    "    return (hue * hue) * (1.0 / SQUARE);\n" +
659
660                    "}\n" +
661                    //// way too much orange?
662//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
663//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
664//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
665//                    "    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
666//                    "          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
667//                    "          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
668//                    "          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
669//                    "          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
670//                    "          + hue *    5.883)))));\n" +
671//                    "}\n" +
672//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
673//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
674//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
675//                    "    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
676//                    "          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
677//                    "          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
678//                    "          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
679//                    "          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
680//                    "          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
681//                    "}\n" +
682                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
683                    "{\n" +
684                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
685                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
686                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
687                    "\n" +
688                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
689                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
690                    "    return vec4(official2primaries(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps))), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
691                    "}\n" +
692                    "\n" +
693                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
694                    "{\n" +
695                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
696                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(primaries2official(c.x) + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
697                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
698                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
699                    "}";
700    /**
701     * This GLSL snippet takes an RGB vec3 and a float that represents a hue rotation in radians, and returns the
702     * rotated RGB vec3. It is not a full shader, and is used by inserting it into shader code to provide the applyHue()
703     * method to that code.
704     * <br>
705     * Credit for this challenging method goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
706     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
707     */
708    public static final String partialHueRodrigues =
709            "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
710                    "{\n" +
711                    "    vec3 k = vec3(0.57735);\n" +
712                    "    float c = cos(hue);\n" +
713                    "    //Rodrigues' rotation formula\n" +
714                    "    return rgb * c + cross(k, rgb) * sin(hue) + k * dot(k, rgb) * (1.0 - c);\n" +
715                    "}\n";
716
717
718    /**
719     * Treats the color as hue, saturation, lightness, and... uh... well, this is pretty much only useful when the batch
720     * color's {@code a} is 1 . You probably want {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} or {@link #fragmentShaderHSLA}.
721     * <br>
722     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
723     */
724    public static final String fragmentShaderHSL =
725            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
726                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
727                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
728                    "#else\n" +
729                    "#define LOWP \n" +
730                    "#endif\n" +
731                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
732                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
733                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
734                    partialCodeHSL +
735                    "void main()\n" +
736                    "{\n" +
737                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
738                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
739                    "   hsl.x = fract((fract(v_color.x + 0.5 - hsl.x) - 0.5) * v_color.w + hsl.x);\n" +
740                    "   hsl.yz = mix(hsl.yz, v_color.yz, v_color.w);\n" +
741                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
742                    "}";
743
744    /**
745     * I can't even remember what this does, to be honest. It's probably not what you want. Instead, you probably want
746     * {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} or {@link #fragmentShaderHSLA}.
747     * <br>
748     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
749     */
750    public static final String fragmentShaderRotateHSL =
751            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
752                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
753                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
754                    "#else\n" +
755                    "#define LOWP \n" +
756                    "#endif\n" +
757                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
758                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
759                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
760                    partialCodeHSL +
761                    "void main()\n" +
762                    "{\n" +
763                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
764                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
765                    "   hsl.x = fract(v_color.x + hsl.x + 0.5);\n" +
766                    "   hsl.yz = clamp(hsl.yz * v_color.yz * 2.0, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
767                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
768                    "}";
769
770    /**
771     * This is similar to the default vertex shader from libGDX, but also sets a varying value for contrast. It is
772     * needed if you use {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}.
773     */
774    public static final String vertexShaderHSLC = "attribute vec4 a_position;\n"
775            + "attribute vec4 a_color;\n"
776            + "attribute vec2 a_texCoord0;\n"
777            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
778            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
779            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" 
780            + "varying float v_lightFix;\n"
781            + "\n"
782            + "void main()\n"
783            + "{\n"
784            + "   v_color = a_color;\n"
785            + "   v_texCoords = a_texCoord0;\n"
786            + "   v_color.a = pow(v_color.a * (255.0/254.0) + 0.5, 1.709);\n"    
787            + "   v_lightFix = 1.0 + pow(v_color.a, 1.41421356);\n"
788            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * a_position;\n"
789            + "}\n";
790
791    /**
792     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Contrast, with hue as a rotation. If hue continuously goes from 0 to 1,
793     * then 0 to 1, 0 to 1, and so on, then this will smoothly rotate the hue of the image.
794     * <br>
795     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
796     * <br>
797     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
798     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
799     * The YCC adaptation, and different approach to contrast (this has close to neutral contrast when a is 0.5,
800     * while the original had a fair bit higher contrast than expected), is from this codebase.
801     * <br>
802     * Meant only for use with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so contrast can
803     * use it.
804     */
805    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC = 
806                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
807                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
808                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
809                    "#else\n" +
810                    "#define LOWP \n" +
811                    "#endif\n" +
812                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
813                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
814                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
815                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
816                            partialHueRodrigues +
817                    "void main()\n" +
818                    "{\n" +
819                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
820                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
821                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
822                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
823                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
824                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
825                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
826                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
827                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
828                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
829                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
830                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
831                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
832                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
833                    "}";
834    /**
835     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Alpha, with hue as a rotation.
836     * <br>
837     * You can generate HSLA colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
838     * <br>
839     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
840     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
841     * The YCC adaptation, and change to use alpha, is from this codebase.
842     * <br>
843     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShader}, unlike what {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} expects.
844     */
845    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLA = 
846                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
847                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
848                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
849                    "#else\n" +
850                    "#define LOWP \n" +
851                    "#endif\n" +
852                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
853                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
854                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
855                            partialHueRodrigues +
856                    "void main()\n" +
857                    "{\n" +
858                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
859                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
860                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
861                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
862                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
863                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
864                    "     (dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)) + brightness),\n" + // lightness
865                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
866                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
867                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
868                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
869                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
870                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
871                    "     tgt.a * v_color.w), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
872                    "}";
873    /**
874     * Generally a lower-quality hue rotation than {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}; this is here as a work in progress.
875     * <br>
876     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
877     * <br>
878     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
879     * contrast can use it.
880     * <br>
881     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
882     */
883    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC2 = 
884                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
885                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
886                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
887                    "#else\n" +
888                    "#define LOWP \n" +
889                    "#endif\n" +
890                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
891                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
892                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
893                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
894                            partialCodeHSL +
895                    "void main()\n" +
896                    "{\n" +
897                    "    float hue = (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
898                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
899                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
900                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
901                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
902                    "    tgt.r = fract(tgt.r + hue);\n" +
903                    "    tgt = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
904                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
905                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
906                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
907                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
908                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
909                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
910                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
911                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
912                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
913                    "}";
914    /**
915     * Cycles lightness in a psychedelic way as hue and lightness change; not a general-purpose usage.
916     * <br>
917     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
918     * <br>
919     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
920     * contrast can use it.
921     * <br>
922     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
923     */
924    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC3 =
925            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
926                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
927                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
928                    "#else\n" +
929                    "#define LOWP \n" +
930                    "#endif\n" +
931                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
932                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
933                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
934                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
935                    "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
936                    partialHueRodrigues +
937                    "void main()\n" +
938                    "{\n" +
939                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
940                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
941                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
942                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
943                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
944                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
945                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix),\n" + // lightness
946                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
947                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
948                    "    tgt.r = sin((tgt.r + brightness) * 6.2831853) * 0.5 + 0.5;\n" +
949                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
950                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
951                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
952                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
953                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
954                    "}";
955    /**
956     * Cycles hue, but not lightness; otherwise this is like {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC3} without contrast, and keeping
957     * alpha intact. Internally, this uses Sam Hocevar's RGB/HSL conversion instead of Andrey-Postelzhuk's HSLC code.
958     * <br>
959     * You can generate HSLA colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
960     * <br>
961     * Expects the vertex shader to be {@link #vertexShader}, not the HSLC variant.
962     * <br>
963     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
964     */
965    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLPsychedelic =
966            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
967                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
968                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
969                    "#else\n" +
970                    "#define LOWP \n" +
971                    "#endif\n" +
972                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
973                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
974                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
975                    partialCodeHSL +
976                    "void main()\n" +
977                    "{\n" +
978                    "    float hue = v_color.x - 0.5;\n" +
979                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
980                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
981                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
982                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
983                    "    tgt.x = fract(tgt.x + hue);\n" +
984                    "    tgt.y = clamp(tgt.y * saturation, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
985                    "    tgt.z = clamp(brightness + tgt.z, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
986                    "    gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
987                    "}";
988
989    /**
990     * One of the more useful HSL shaders here, this takes a batch color as hue, saturation, lightness, and power,
991     * with hue as a target hue and power used to determine how much of the target color should be used. There is no
992     * neutral value for hue, saturation, or lightness, but if power is 0, then the source color will be used
993     * exactly. On the other hand, if power is 1.0, then all pixels will be the target color. Hue is specified from
994     * 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0 as red, about 0.3 as green, about 0.6 as blue, etc. Saturation is specified from 0.0 to 1.0,
995     * with 0.0 as grayscale and 1.0 as a fully-saturated target color. Lightness is specified from 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0
996     * as black, the 0.3 to 0.7 range as most colors, and 1.0 white; saturation is clamped to a smaller value as
997     * lightness moves away from 0.5 (toward black or white).
998     * <br>
999     * You can generate HSL(P) colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
1000     */
1001    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLP =
1002            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1003                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1004                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1005                    "#else\n" +
1006                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1007                    "#endif\n" +
1008                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1009                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1010                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1011                    partialCodeHSL +
1012                    "void main()\n" +
1013                    "{\n" +
1014                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1015                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
1016                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(cos(hsl.x * 6.2831853), sin(hsl.x * 6.2831853)) * hsl.y;\n" +
1017                    "   vec3 tint = vec3(cos(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y, sin(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y, v_color.z);\n" +
1018                    "   hsl.xyz = mix(hsl.xyz, tint, v_color.w);\n" +
1019                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(fract(atan(hsl.y, hsl.x) / 6.2831853), length(hsl.xy));\n" +
1020                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
1021                    "}";
1022
1023    /**
1024     * This is supposed to look for RGBA colors that are similar to {@code search}, and if it finds
1025     * one, to replace it with {@code replace} (also an RGBA color). It isn't great at the searching part.
1026     * <br>
1027     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1028     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1029     * <br>
1030     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
1031     */
1032    public static final String fragmentShaderReplacement = 
1033                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1034                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1035                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1036                    "#else\n" +
1037                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1038                    "#endif\n" +
1039                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1040                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1041                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1042                    "uniform vec4 u_search;\n" +
1043                    "uniform vec4 u_replace;\n" +
1044                    "void main()\n" +
1045                    "{\n" +
1046                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
1047                    "   float curve = smoothstep(0.0, 1.0, 1.25 - distance(tgt.rgb, u_search.rgb) * 2.0);\n" +
1048                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4(mix(tgt.rgb, u_replace.rgb, curve), tgt.a) * v_color;\n" +
1049                    "}";
1050    /**
1051     * A drop-in replacement for the default fragment shader that eliminates lightness differences in the output colors.
1052     * Specifically, it does the normal SpriteBatch shader's step with the multiplicative batch color, converts to IPT,
1053     * sets intensity to 0.5, shrinks the P and T components so the color is less saturated, and then converts back to
1054     * an RGBA color. Even though this uses IPT internally, it expects the batch color to be normal RGBA.
1055     * <br>
1056     * Editing this shader is strongly encouraged to fit your needs!
1057     * <br>
1058     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1059     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1060     * <br>
1061     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
1062     * @see #fragmentShaderConfigurableContrast a per-sprite-configurable version of this
1063     */
1064    public static String fragmentShaderFlatLightness =
1065  "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1066  "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1067  "precision mediump float;\n" +
1068  "#else\n" +
1069  "#define LOWP \n" +
1070  "#endif\n" +
1071  "#define TARGET_LIGHTNESS 0.5 \n" +
1072  "#define SATURATION_CHANGE 1.0 \n" +
1073  "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1074  "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1075  "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1076  "void main()\n" +
1077  "{\n" +
1078  "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1079  "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
1080  "         * (tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb));\n" +
1081  "    ipt.x = TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // change to desired lightness or pass in a lightness as a uniform
1082  "//    ipt.x = (ipt.x - 0.5) * 0.25 + TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // an alternative way that preserves a tiny bit of original lightness
1083  "    ipt.yz *= SATURATION_CHANGE;\n" + // multiplies saturation by SATURATION_CHANGE, which may be more or less than 1.0
1084  "    vec3 back = clamp(mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1085  "    gl_FragColor = vec4(back, v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
1086  "}";
1087    /**
1088     * A specialized shader that can reduce lightness differences in the output colors, saturate/desaturate them, and
1089     * can be configured to use some of the existing lightness in the image to add to a main flat lightness.
1090     * Specifically, it takes the fragment color (typically a pixel in a texture), converts to IPT, does a calculation
1091     * involving the intensity of the fragment color where the batch color's blue channel affects how much that
1092     * intensity is used, adds the red channel of the batch color, multiplies the P and T components by the green
1093     * channel times 2.0 to saturate or desaturate, and then converts back to an RGBA color. The neutral value for this
1094     * is the RGBA color 0.5, 0.5, 1.0, 1.0 . A typical usage to achieve a fog effect would be to raise lightness (r),
1095     * slightly reduce saturation (g), sharply flatten the original texture's lightness (b), and leave alpha alone (a):
1096     * 0.7, 0.4, 0.2, 1.0 .
1097     * <br>
1098     * This doesn't use a standard type of color; you should use something like
1099     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)} to set the channels in
1100     * the specific way this uses them.
1101     * <br>
1102     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
1103     * @see #fragmentShaderFlatLightness if you only need one contrast setting and still want to set color tints
1104     */
1105    public static String fragmentShaderConfigurableContrast =
1106            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1107                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1108                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1109                    "#else\n" +
1110                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1111                    "#endif\n" +
1112                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1113                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1114                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1115                    "void main()\n" +
1116                    "{\n" +
1117                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1118                    "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
1119                    "         * tgt.rgb);\n" +
1120                    "    ipt.x = (ipt.x - 0.5) * v_color.b + v_color.r;\n" + // preserves some lightness based on b, sets main lightness with r
1121                    "    ipt.yz *= v_color.g * 2.0;\n" + // the green channel affects saturation; if it's 0.5 it won't change saturation.
1122                    "    vec3 back = clamp(mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1123                    "    gl_FragColor = vec4(back, v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
1124                    "}";
1125
1126    /**
1127     * A day/night cycle shader that can be used without any other parts of this library. This only needs setting the
1128     * uniform {@code u_timeOfDay} to any float; the rate at which you change this float affects how fast the day/night
1129     * cycle occurs. This is meant to be used with {@link #fragmentShaderDayNight}. Together, they make the color
1130     * adjustment go from bluish and dark at night, to purplish at dawn, to orange/yellow and bright at mid-day, toward
1131     * red at dusk, and then back to bluish at night. This uses an RGBA batch color.
1132     * <br>
1133     * Editing this shader is strongly encouraged to fit your needs! The time-based variables st, ct, and dd can all be
1134     * adjusted to increase or decrease the strength of the effect, and their effects can also be adjusted upon v_color
1135     * and v_tweak.
1136     * <br>
1137     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1138     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1139     */
1140    public static String vertexShaderDayNight = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
1141            + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
1142            + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
1143            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
1144            + "uniform float u_timeOfDay;\n"
1145            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
1146            + "varying vec4 v_tweak;\n"
1147            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
1148            + "varying float v_lightFix;\n"
1149            + "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n"
1150            + "\n"
1151            + "void main()\n"
1152            + "{\n"
1153            + "   float st = sin(1.5707963 * sin(0.2617994 * u_timeOfDay)); // Whenever st is very high or low... \n"
1154            + "   float ct = sin(1.5707963 * cos(0.2617994 * u_timeOfDay)); // ...ct is close to 0, and vice versa. \n"
1155            + "   float dd = ct * ct; // Positive, small; used for dawn and dusk. \n"
1156            + "   v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
1157            + "   v_color.w = v_color.w * (255.0/254.0);\n"
1158            + "   vec3 oklab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *"
1159            + "     pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n"
1160            + "     * (v_color.rgb * v_color.rgb), forward);\n"
1161            + "   // The next four lines make use of the time-based variables st, ct, and dd. Edit to fit. \n"
1162            + "   v_color.x = clamp(oklab.x + (0.0625 * st), 0.0, 1.0);\n"
1163            + "   v_color.yz = clamp(oklab.yz + vec2(0.0625 * dd + 0.03125 * st, 0.1 * st), -1.0, 1.0) * ((dd + 0.25) * 0.5);\n"
1164            + "   v_tweak = vec4(0.2 * st + 0.5);\n"
1165            + "   v_tweak.w = pow((1.0 - 0.125 * st), 1.709);\n"
1166            + "   v_lightFix = 1.0 + pow(v_tweak.w, 1.41421356);\n"
1167            + "   v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
1168            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
1169            + "}\n";
1170    /**
1171     * The fragment shader counterpart to {@link #vertexShaderDayNight}; must be used with that vertex shader. See its
1172     * docs for more info, particularly about the one uniform this needs set. This uses an RGBA batch color.
1173     * <br>
1174     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1175     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1176     * <br>
1177     * Meant only for use with {@link #vertexShaderDayNight}.
1178     */
1179    public static String fragmentShaderDayNight =
1180            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1181                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1182                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1183                    "#else\n" +
1184                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1185                    "#endif\n" +
1186                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1187                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1188                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_tweak;\n" +
1189                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
1190                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1191                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n" +
1192                    "void main()\n" +
1193                    "{\n" +
1194                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1195                    "  vec3 lab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *" +
1196                    "             pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n" +
1197                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
1198                    "  lab.x = clamp(pow(lab.x, v_tweak.w) * v_lightFix * v_tweak.x + v_color.x - 1.0, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1199                    "  lab.yz = clamp((lab.yz * v_tweak.yz + v_color.yz) * 1.5, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
1200                    "  lab = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, +0.3963377774, -0.1055613458, -0.0894841775, +0.2158037573, -0.0638541728, -1.2914855480) * lab;\n" +
1201                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
1202                    "                 mat3(+4.0767245293, -1.2681437731, -0.0041119885, -3.3072168827, +2.6093323231, -0.7034763098, +0.2307590544, -0.3411344290, +1.7068625689) *\n" +
1203                    "                 (lab * lab * lab)," +
1204                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
1205                    "}";
1206
1207    /**
1208     * Takes a batch color in CIE LAB format (but ranging from 0 to 1 instead of its normal larger range).
1209     * Adapted from <a href="https://www.shadertoy.com/view/lsdGzN">This ShaderToy by nmz</a>.
1210     * <br>
1211     * You can generate CIELAB colors using any of various methods in the {@code cielab} package, such as
1212     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.cielab.ColorTools#cielab(float, float, float, float)}.
1213     * <br>
1214     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
1215     */
1216    public static String fragmentShaderCielab =
1217            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1218            "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1219            "precision mediump float;\n" +
1220            "#else\n" +
1221            "#define LOWP \n" +
1222            "#endif\n" +
1223            "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1224            "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
